Scheme 1 Simplified scheme of catalyst beds with ZSM-5 zeolite and γ-Al2O3 matrix catalysts alone and then mixed in a staged bed configuration. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Proposed reaction route for the MTP reaction with co-fed ethanol on the commercial MTP catalyst. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 (a) Optical photograph of fresh (white) and spent (dark) MTP catalysts; (b) SEM images of fresh MTP catalyst; (c) mapping image of Al atoms in the red section of image b; (d) XRD pattern of the fresh MTP catalyst; (e) 27Al NMR spectra of the fresh MTP catalyst; (f) 29Si NMR spectra of the fresh MTP catalyst; and (g) pore size distribution and N2 sorption curves (inset) of the fresh MTP catalyst (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Physiochemical properties of the commercial ZSM-5 zeolite and γ-Al2O3: (a) XRD patterns; (b) N2 sorption curves and pore size distributions; (c) pyridine-adsorbed FT-IR spectra; (d) SEM image of the commercial ZSM-5 zeolite; and (e & f) TEM images of γ-Al2O3. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Conversion percentage (a) and olefin selectivity for MTP reactions vs. time-on-stream with varying feeds: pure methanol (b); and mixed with 10 wt.% (c); 20 wt.% (d); 35 wt.% (e); and 50 wt.% (f) ethanol. Conditions: WHSV of methanol =4.0 h−1, 470 °C, 0.1 MPa, and catalyst=0.10 g. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Methane selectivity (a) and C5+ selectivity (b) for MTP reactions vs. time on stream with varying feed compositions. Conditions: WHSV of methanol =4.0 h−1, 470 °C, 0.1 MPa, and catalyst=0.10 g. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Comparison of the conversion and product selectivities versus reaction temperatures with the pure methanol feed over the (a) commercial MTP catalyst, (b) ZSM-5 catalyst alone, (c) γ-Al2O3 catalyst alone, and (d) 30 % Al2O3/70 % ZSM-5 staged bed catalyst. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Comparison of the conversion and product selectivities versus reaction temperatures with the pure ethanol feed over the (a) commercial MTP catalyst, (b) ZSM-5 catalyst alone, (c) γ-Al2O3 catalyst alone, and (d) 30 % Al2O3/70 % ZSM-5 staged bed catalyst. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Reactivity comparison of methanol and ethanol on the ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Conditions: 470 °C, 0.1 MPa, at different WHSVs of methanol or ethanol. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Conversion and product selectivities of the MTP reactions vs. time-on-stream over the commercial MTP catalyst while using a feed of methanol mixed with (a) 20 wt.% H2O and (b) 20 wt.% isopropanol. Conditions: WHSV of methanol =4.0 h−1, 470 °C, 0.1 MPa, and catalyst =0.10 g. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Acid strength detected by the NH3-TPD analysis (a) and N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distributions (b) of as-received fresh and spent commercial MTP catalysts. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 FT-IR spectra variation (a) and weight loss (b) of commercial MTP catalysts in the MTP reaction over time on stream. Conditions: WHSV of methanol =4.0 h−1, 470 °C, 0.1 MPa, and 0.10 g of catalyst. Fig. 10 Table 1 Physiochemical properties of the MTP catalyst and pure ZSM-5 zeolite and γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Graphical abstract Proposed reaction route for the MTP reaction with co-fed ethanol on the MTP catalyst. In this work, co-feeding ethanol with methanol was adopted to prolong the lifetime of a catalyst in a methanol to propylene (MTP) reaction. The effect of an ethanol additive on the MTP reaction was further investigated over an MTP catalyst, pure catalysts of ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3, and a mixed catalyst of ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3, by using methanol and ethanol alone. The catalytic performance showed that with an increasing addition of ethanol, the lifetime of the commercial MTP catalyst was greatly improved, and the selectivity for ethylene correspondingly increased. The catalytic performances of methanol and ethanol on different catalysts showed that the reactivity of methanol and ethanol were in the following order: ethanol on ZSM-5 > ethanol on γ-Al2O3 > methanol on ZSM-5 > methanol on γ-Al2O3. Moreover, coke deposition on moderately strong and strong acid sites and pore blockage were responsible for catalyst deactivation. Keywords MTP reaction Propylene Ethanol Catalyst lifetime ZSM-5 zeolite 1 Introduction Light olefins, including ethylene, propylene, and butylene are important; additionally, they are some of the most-produced basic organic chemical materials, being mainly produced by petrochemical industries. However, due to an ever-increasing cost of crude oil and the demand for light olefins, a methanol conversion process has been developed as the most successful and attractive alternative to produce light olefins. This process is chosen due to the wide range of raw material sources, such as coal and biomass, for producing methanol. Methanol to olefins (MTO) and methanol to propylene (MTP) processes have been used in industry for a dozen years. The MTO process uses a SAPO-34 zeotype catalyst, which is a molecular sieve with an 8-membered ring, large CHA cages and a narrow pore opening (0.38 nm × 0.38 nm) that promotes a high selectivity to light olefins (>80 %) [1,2]. Notably, a fluidized bed reactor is needed due to a rapid deactivation caused by coke trapping in the cages of SAPO-34 [3]. In contrast, a fixed bed MTP process uses a ZSM-5 zeotype catalyst, which has a three-dimensional 10-membered ring micropore (0.51 nm × 0.55 nm zigzag channels and 0.53 nm × 0.56 nm intersecting straight channels) in an MFI framework; the above process predominantly produces propylene, and the high propylene-to-ethylene (P/E) ratio of the process is due to the unique porosity and surface acidity of the catalyst [4–6]. To date, in an industrial MTP process developed by Lurgi Company, at 350−500 °C and an atmospheric pressure, a one-pass propylene selectivity of at least 35 % has been achieved. The ZSM-5-based catalyst should be regenerated approximately every 450 h by online roasting to remove deposited coke [7,8]. To reduce operation costs, numerous efforts have been devoted to improving the lifetime of the catalyst. Most studies focus on improving the diffusion efficiency of coke precursors in the microporous channels of ZSM-5 by shortening diffusion lengths with hierarchical porous structure designs, zeolite sizes and/or morphology-controllable preparations. On the other hand, practical use of zeolite-based granular catalysts in a fixed bed reactor, require binders such as alumina or silica to increase the mechanical strength, active site accessibility, and thermal stability of the catalyst. However, until now, there are few reports on the effect of the binder on the catalytic performance in the MTP reaction [9,10]. For example, Pérez-Uriarte et al. [11] investigated the effect of different binders on the dimethyl ether (DME) transformation to olefins over a ZSM-5 zeolite and found that γ-Al2O3 with weak acidity and a mesoporous structure contributed to the stability of the catalyst. In our previous study, crude methanol feed, which contains a small amount of light carbon alcohols (approximately 0.36 wt.%), was industrially tested in commercial plants [12]. The experimental results showed that degraded methanol feed had no obvious influence on the conversion and selectivity of the process, while the catalyst lifetime slightly increased. In a proposed dual-cycle mechanism for methanol conversion inside zeolites, it is generally accepted that there are two routes for light olefin formation: (i) methylation-dealkylation of aromatics (a type of polymethylbenzene) and (ii) methylation-cracking of olefins [13–15]. Many studies show that a coexistence of aromatics and olefins inside the zeolites leads to a competition between the two cycles, and product distributions can be adjusted by co-feeding aromatic species and olefins with methanol [6,16,17]. Recently, Lercher et al. [17] reported in an elegant paper the impact on obtained product distributions by coprocessing low concentrations of aromatics (benzene, toluene and xylenes) and olefins (ethane, propene, 1-butene, 1-pentene, and 1-hexene) with methanol over an HZSM-5 catalyst. In another paper by Lercher’s group, co-feeding small concentrations of higher alcohols was found to significantly increase the catalyst lifetime, which was attributed to the alcohols promoting a different coking pathway [6]· This contribution aims to determine the effect of co-feeding ethanol in an MTP reaction and to examine the underlying mechanistic principles in product variations induced by ethanol additives. We investigated the catalytic performance of a commercial MTP catalyst in the MTP reaction with different amounts of co-fed ethanol. The catalytic performances of four types of catalysts, including the MTP catalyst, pure ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts and a mixed catalyst of ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3, were evaluated in pure methanol and pure ethanol reactions; this was to explain the mechanism for improving the lifetime of the catalyst in regard to low carbon alcohol reactions over the ZSM-5 framework and γ-Al2O3 binder. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts In this study, a commercial MTP catalyst sample, which was supplied by Shenhua Ningxia Coal Industry Group Co., Ltd, was used. The spent commercial MTP catalyst was unloaded from the industrial plant without further treatment. A commercial H-form ZSM-5 zeolite with a SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratio of 100 was purchased from Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd. and used as received. γ-Al2O3 was obtained from pseudoboehmite (Al2O3 content is 71.90 wt.% on a dry basis, provided by Hua Xin powder Co. Ltd.) by calcination at 550 °C for 4 h in air. Methanol, ethanol, and isopropanol with analytical purities were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. and used without any further purification. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to analyze the crystallinity of the sample structure. Patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance Diffractometer with CuK-Alpha1 radiation (0.15406 nm) over a 2θ range of 5° to 75°, with operating parameters of 40 kV and 30 mA, and a scanning speed of 0.02°/s. Low-temperature N2 sorption was performed at −196 °C on a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 to characterize the textural properties of the samples. Prior to the measurement, the samples were outgassed at 350 °C for 4 h to remove any physically adsorbed moisture. 29Si and 27Al Magic Angle Spinning Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (MAS NMR) measurements were performed by using an Advance III HD 600 MHz instrument operating at 119.2 MHz. The acquisition of 48 kHz MAS spectra was obtained by using a Bruker 4.0 mm double-resonance MAS detector, with the use of a single pulse sequence and an RF-pulse duration of 5 μs. The elemental compositions of the commercial MTP catalyst were obtained from X-ray fluorescence (XRF) recorded on an AXIOS-Petro spectrometer. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images were taken on a Quanta 250 instrument equipped with energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS) for elemental mapping. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) analysis was used to characterize the acidity of the samples on a Nicolet iS5 (Nicolet Instrument, Thermo Company, USA) instrument, using pyridine as a probe molecule, the acid amounts were semi-quantitatively calculated based on the IR band areas according to the report by Emeis et al. [18]. The acid strength of the samples was also checked by a temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) on a Quanta Chrome ChemStar™ instrument. A thermogravimetric analysis (TG) of spent catalysts was performed with a Netzch STA449F5 analyzer. 2.3 Catalytic tests of the MTP reactions The catalysts were pressed at 5 tons, crushed and then sieved through a 40–60 mesh. The methanol to propylene (MTP) reactions were performed on a homemade fixed bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. The catalyst (0.10 g) was placed in a quartz reactor with an inner diameter of 6 mm and pretreated before the test at 550 °C for 1 h in an argon gas flow of 50 mL/min. The feed was injected into the reactor under an argon carrier gas at a flow rate of 50 mL/min. The MTP reactions were carried out with a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 4.0 h−1 for the feed. The reaction products were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (GC 2014C, Shimadzu) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionized detector (FID) using a TG-BONG Q (30 m ×0.32 mm ×10 μm) column operating at 50−180 °C. The methanol conversion was defined as usual: X M e O H = ( m M e O H i n - 1.39 m D M E ( o u t ) - m M e O H o u t ) m M e O H ( i n ) The selectivity to the i product was defined as follows: S i = m i Σ m i where mi is the mass weight of the compound i, and Σ mi is the total mass weight of all products. The DME product was regarded as two molecules of unconverted methanol. The mass balance was carefully controlled with an average error within 3 %. For comparison, the pure ZSM-5 zeolite and γ-Al2O3 matrix were used as catalysts and tested in the same reactor. Three types of catalyst bed configurations were adopted using 0.10 g of catalyst, as shown in Scheme 1 . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physiochemical properties of the commercial MTP catalyst The physiochemical properties of the commercial MTP catalyst were characterized, and the results are displayed in Fig. 1 . Fig. 1a shows the geometry and morphology of the fresh and spent commercial MTP catalysts engineered at a macro scale, which have rod-like structures of approximately 7 mm in length and approximately 4 mm in diameter. Compared to that of the fresh MTP catalyst, grain breakage is observed for the spent MTP catalyst due to mechanical damage after several uses in the plant. The TEM image in Fig. 1b shows the rough surface of the fresh MTP catalyst and the dispersion of zeolite and matrix, which can be verified by the uniform distribution of Al atoms, as shown in Fig. 1c. The XRD pattern (Fig. 1d) shows that the MTP catalyst exhibits the MFI framework, for which the main characteristic peaks appear at 2θ of 8.0°, 8.9°, 23.2°, 24.0°, and 24.5°, corresponding to (101), (200), (332), (051) and (303), respectively (JCPSD no. 44-0003) [19–21]. However, a shaped commercial MTP catalyst contains a binder such as alumina to improve mechanical stability. The 29Si and 27Al NMR spectra in Fig. 1e and f provide the coordination states of the atoms in the MTP catalyst. The 29Si NMR spectrum in Fig. 1e shows the presence of two characteristic peaks: (i) Si surrounded by three Si or Al atoms and one hydroxyl group (Si(1Al)) and (ii) Si surrounded by four Si or Al atoms (Si(0Al)). They appear at chemical shifts of -105 and higher than 107 ppm, respectively [22]. In view of the dominant composition of the ZSM-5 zeolite (Fig. 1d), the aluminum atoms displayed in the 29Si NMR spectra are most likely attributed to the framework Al species, and the framework SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratio is 208, as calculated from the fitted peaks. The existence of the alumina binder can be demonstrated by an aluminum species coordination from the 27Al spectrum (Fig. 1f). This shows that the MTP catalyst has two types of four-coordinated framework (AlIV) and two types of six-coordinated extra-framework (AlVI) aluminum species at approximately 0 ppm and 60 ppm, respectively. In addition, a small quantity of five-coordinated aluminum species (AlV) is also observed at approximately 35 ppm. For well-crystallized ZSM-5 zeolite, only tetrahedral framework aluminum species at approximately 0 ppm should be observed [23]. However, the ratio of extra-framework AlVI to framework AlIV aluminum species is 1.79, which is calculated from the fitted peaks. Therefore, the six-coordinated aluminum species are most likely to originate from the alumina-based binder, although no apparent peak of alumina is observed in the XRD pattern (Fig. 1d). The textural properties of the MTP catalysts were investigated by N2 sorption measurements (Fig. 1g and Table 1 ). This shows that the MTP catalyst has a type-IV isotherm with an obvious hysteresis loop corresponding to a mesoporous structure. The pore size distribution exhibits broad mesopore sizes in the range of 3−15 nm, which is consistent with the pore sizes of alumina. Meanwhile, the N2 isotherm exhibits a sharp uptake at P/P0 < 0.02, indicating the presence of microporosity, which comes from the crystallized ZSM-5 zeolite. Thus, the mesoporosity probably mainly comes from the alumina-based binder. 3.2 Physiochemical Properties of the commercial ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 For comparison, pure catalysts of ZSM-5 zeolite and γ-Al2O3 were also measured and tested. The physiochemical properties of the two catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The XRD patterns in Fig. 2a show that ZSM-5 zeolite exhibits strong characteristic peaks of the MFI framework, similar to that of the MTP catalyst in Fig. 1d. In contrast, γ-Al2O3 has a much weaker intensity of characteristic peaks of the gamma alumina phase (JCPDS no. 10-0425). In light of the obvious difference in peak intensities, commercial MTP catalysts possess both ZSM-5 zeolite and alumina matrices, although no apparent peak of alumina was observed in the XRD pattern (Fig. 1d). N2 sorption measurements (Fig. 2b and Table 1) show that the pure ZSM-5 catalyst has a type-I isotherm with a nearly invisible hysteresis loop; in contrast, γ-Al2O3 possesses type IV sorption curves typical of mesoporous materials, according to the IUPAC classification. The plateau in the isotherms at high relative pressures indicates the absence of macroporosity or interparticle mesoporosity. Pore size distributions show that γ-Al2O3 exhibits broad mesopore sizes of approximately 2−40 nm and a large pore volume of approximately 0.673 cm3 g−1, while pure ZSM-5 mainly possesses microporosity with a mesoporous volume of 0.040 cm3 g−1 (Table 1). The pyridine-adsorbed FT-IR spectra of the two samples and their corresponding surface acid properties are displayed in Fig. 1c and Table 1. The detailed assignments of bands are similar to that we previously reported [24–26]. Namely, the bands at approximately 1546 and 1444 cm−1 are respectively attributed to pyridine-adsorbed Brönsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites. Obviously, γ-Al2O3 only possesses Lewis acid sites of 17.81 μmol g−1. Pure ZSM-5, in contrast, has both Lewis and Brönsted acid sites of up to 59.64 and 153.84 μmol g−1, respectively, which is much higher than that of γ-Al2O3, as shown in Table 1. The morphologies of the pure ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 are shown in Figs. 2d-2f. The SEM micrograph in Fig. 2d reveals that the crystal structure of the as-received ZSM-5 zeolite is quadrangular in shape. The TEM micrographs in Figs. 2e and f show uniform distributions of short, nanosized rod-like crystals of as-prepared γ-Al2O3. In addition, the broad diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 indicate a small-sized crystalline alumina of approximately 5.2 nm; the above value is calculated by the Debye-Scherrer formula that uses the FWHM from the XRD reflections of the (400) and (440) planes. 3.3 Catalytic performance of co-feeding ethanol over the commercial MTP catalyst Figs. 3 and 4 show the relationship between the methanol to propylene (MTP) reaction and product selectivity as a function of time on stream using methanol and co-fed ethanol over the commercial MTP catalyst at 470 °C. A wide variety of products, including methane (CH4), ethylene (C2 =), propylene (C3 =), butylene (C4 =), hydrocarbon products with five or more carbon atoms (C5+), and light paraffins (mainly butanes), have been observed in the analysis, as shown in Table 2 . Fig. 3a comparatively shows the methanol conversion as a function of time on stream for the MTP reaction with an increase of co-fed ethanol. It can be found that the methanol conversion proceeded with a high (>99.9 %) stability for 25 h on stream. Thereafter, methanol conversion of the pure methanol feed decreased quickly. In contrast, the lifetimes of the MTP catalysts increased with an increase in co-fed ethanol, and the methanol conversion decreased more slowly. Here, the catalyst lifetime was defined as the reaction time for a catalyst with a methanol conversion higher than 85 %, and the ethanol additive was completely converted in the MTP reaction conditions in this work. As for selectivity to light olefins (C2 =∼C4 =), C2 = selectivity obviously increased with the increase of ethanol addition, rising from 8.98 wt.% to 69.48 wt.%. Interestingly, C2 = selectivity gradually increased with time on stream, while the selectivity of propylene and butylene gradually decreased with time on stream, as shown in Figs. 3c-3f. As a result, the ratio of propylene to ethylene (P/E) quickly decreased. In view of completely conversion of ethanol, ethylene selectivity and propylene selectivity originated from the ethanol reaction should be stable no matter what content of ethanol was used. However, Fig. 3 shows that with increasing the reaction time, ethylene selectivity gradually increased while propylene selectivity gradually decreased, which also led to the decrease of P/E ratios as a function of time on stream. Besides, the methylation activity of light olefins decreases with increasing the carbon numbers of light olefins [16]. In this case, the increased ethylene concentration at higher ethanol addition decreased the methylation-cracking rate between propylene and methanol but increased the methylation-cracking rate between ethylene and methanol. The average selectivity to light olefins gradually increased from 55.84 wt.% to 88.97 wt.% when the ethanol addition increased from zero to 50 wt.%, as shown in Table 2. Fig. 4 shows that the methane selectivity for the MTP reaction using pure methanol feed obviously increased with time on stream. With an increased addition of co-fed ethanol, the rate of increase of CH4 selectivity over time on stream slowly decreased. The C5+ product selectivity showed similar performance to those presented above, but it was noted that C5+ product selectivity was very high in the initial period of the reaction for 10 wt.% and 35 wt.% ethanol additions compared to that of the pure methanol feed. 3.4 Catalytic performance for methanol or ethanol over the ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts To explore the effects of co-feeding ethanol on the MTP reaction over commercial MTP catalysts, four types of catalysts, including an MTP catalyst, ZSM-5 catalyst alone, γ-Al2O3 catalyst alone and a mixture of ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3, were tested using feed streams of methanol and ethanol alone. Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 show the rates of conversion and product selectivity as a function of temperature on the four catalysts with varied catalyst bed configurations (Scheme 1) using methanol and ethanol, respectively. In Fig. 5a, with the MTP catalyst, methanol conversion increased quickly with increasing reaction temperature. Here, it should be noted that the dimethyl ether (DME) intermediate was detected, which was regarded as an unconverted methanol and not listed separately. It is noted that C4 = selectivity and C5+ product selectivity increased at first, then decreased with time on stream and reached a maximum at approximately 350 °C. Similarly, C3 = selectivity first increased and then declined, reaching a maximum of 53.67 wt.% at approximately 475 °C. In contrast, CH4 selectivity and C2 = selectivity increased slowly with increasing reaction temperature. The catalytic performance of the MTP reaction on the ZSM-5 catalyst alone in Fig. 5b shows similar methanol conversion variations with increasing reaction temperature compared with those on the MTP catalyst. Compared to the MTP catalyst, C4 = selectivity and C5+ product selectivity on the ZSM-5 catalyst followed a similar but more obvious trend; however, with increasing reaction temperature, C2 = selectivity increased more remarkably, while CH4 selectivity decreased, especially at high temperature. C3 = selectivity monotonically increased with increasing reaction temperature on the pure ZSM-5 catalyst, and the light olefin selectivity was the same. In contrast, Fig. 5c shows that methanol conversion on the γ-Al2O3 catalyst alone was negligible when the reaction temperature was below 350 °C. That is, the DME intermediate was the dominant product. With increasing reaction temperature, methanol conversion rose rapidly, up to nearly 100 % at temperatures higher than 500 °C. However, CH4 was the dominant product, while selectivity to other products was below 2 wt.%. This indicated that most of the methanol was converted into methane on the γ-Al2O3 catalyst. In Fig. 5d, the catalysts of 30 wt.% γ-Al2O3 and 70 wt.% ZSM-5 with a staged bed configuration (Scheme 1) possessed nearly 100 % methanol conversion under the test conditions. With increasing reaction temperature, C5+ product selectivity on the staged bed catalyst gradually decreased, while C3 = selectivity at first increased and then decreased, reaching a maximum of 39.33 wt.% at approximately 425 °C. It should be noted that with increasing reaction temperature, CH4 selectivity increased slowly before 425 °C and then increased rapidly, analogous to the variation of CH4 selectivity on the γ-Al2O3 catalyst alone. This means that the initial contact of methanol with the Lewis acid sites on the γ-Al2O3 catalyst is the major contributor for the formation of CH4 products. Fig. 6 shows that ethanol is more reactive than methanol and that ethanol conversions were nearly 100 % over the four catalysts, especially when reaction temperatures were greater than 350 °C. It is worth noting that CH4 selectivity was almost negligible and had no change under the experimental conditions. In Fig. 6a, C2 = was the main product of ethanol conversion on the commercial MTP catalyst, with a value of more than 80 % under the experimental conditions. In contrast, C3 = selectivity was relatively low, with a value of less than 10 %. Compared with the methanol feed alone in Fig. 5a, C4 = selectivity and C5+ product selectivity using the ethanol feed alone were much lower, especially at high reaction temperatures. Fig. 6b shows that C2 = selectivity on the ZSM-5 catalyst alone decreased at first and then increased, reaching a minimum of 46.29 wt.% at 400 °C. In contrast, C3 = selectivity increased at first and then decreased, reaching a maximum of 24.42 wt.% at 400 °C. Fig. 6c shows that ethylene was the primary product of ethanol conversion on γ-Al2O3 alone, while other products could be regarded as negligible. In Fig. 6d, the mixed catalyst of 30 wt.% γ-Al2O3 and 70 wt.% ZSM-5 with a staged bed configuration possessed 100 % ethanol conversion under the test conditions. The variation tendency of products on the staged bed catalyst was similar to that on ZSM-5 alone (as shown in Fig. 6b). This could be attributed to the combined effect of the upper layer of γ-Al2O3 and lower layer of ZSM-5 in the catalyst configuration, leading to higher C2 = selectivity due to the initial contact of ethanol with the upper γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Further study on the reactivity of methanol and ethanol on ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 was carried out at 470 °C by varying the WHSV of the feed. The reaction rates in terms of gcat min−1 mol−1 of methanol or ethanol are displayed in Fig. 7 . The reactivity of ethanol was much higher than the reactivity of methanol, and the reactivity of methanol or ethanol on the ZSM-5 catalyst was much higher than that on the γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The catalytic performances of methanol or ethanol conversion over catalysts of ZSM-5 followed by Al2O3, and the blend of them two were also checked and shown in Fig. S2. Whether methanol or ethanol reaction, ZSM-5 followed by Al2O3 exhibited similar catalytic reactivity and product selectivity to those over pure ZSM-5 catalyst due to the prior contact of methanol/ethanol with ZSM-5 component, which possessed much higher activity than Al2O3 matrix, as shown in Figs. 6 and 7 and Fig. S2. Similarly, and the blend of ZSM-5 and Al2O3 exhibited similar catalytic performances to that of MTP catalyst, however, the propylene selectivities of methanol/ethanol conversion over the former were relatively lower, probably due to its stronger acidity. In addition, with increasing catalyst usage, the increases in methanol and ethanol conversions on the ZSM-5 catalyst were faster than those on the γ-Al2O3 catalyst, most likely due to the comparatively high acid content and the addition of Brönsted acid on the ZSM-5 zeolite, as shown in Table 1. The aforementioned catalytic performances of co-feeding ethanol in the MTP reactions indicate that the addition of ethanol to methanol suppresses the formation of CH4 and C5+ products. As proposed by Lercher et al. [6], methanol itself can be converted to methane and formaldehyde during the initial phase of the MTP reaction, and the reactive formaldehyde molecules are prone to be transformed into oxygenic coke species by undergoing Formose-type reactions and aggregations. In contrast, a deactivation pathway is largely bypassed when small amounts of higher alcohols were co-fed because graphitic type coke species were expected to appear. The relatively much lower deactivation rate of graphitic coke compared to oxygenic coke was thought to be responsible for the longer lifetime of the catalyst. In our study, separate reactions of methanol or ethanol on the four catalysts show that CH4 was primarily derived from methanol conversion on Lewis acid sites of the γ-Al2O3 catalyst, as shown in Scheme 2 . Fig. 7 shows that there was an order of reactivity: ethanol on ZSM-5 > ethanol on γ-Al2O3 > methanol on ZSM-5 > methanol on γ-Al2O3. In this case, when a small amount of ethanol was added, ethanol had the priority over methanol to react on the γ-Al2O3 surface. Thus, methanol was primarily converted on the ZSM-5 component, and ethanol could react on both ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3, resulting in higher ethylene selectivity but lower methane selectivity. In addition, the lifetime of the ZSM-5 catalyst with the pure ethanol feed was much longer than that with the pure methanol feed, as shown in Fig. S3 and Fig. S4. In addition, during the initial stage of ethanol conversion on the ZSM-5 catalyst, a considerable percentage of propylene was observed in Fig. S4. Many studies show that ethanol conversion on ZSM-5 zeolites follows a similar hydrocarbon pool mechanism, such as methanol conversion, resulting in the formation of larger hydrocarbons, such as propylene and C5+ products [27–30]. With an extension of reaction time, in spite of the possible disappearance of strong acid sites due to coke formation, the ZSM-5 catalyst was still capable of converting ethanol to ethylene, which only needed weak acid sites for ethanol dehydration. It could be verified by the long stability of the ethanol conversion demonstrated on the γ-Al2O3 catalyst, which had weaker acidity compared to that of the ZSM-5 catalyst, as shown in Table 1, Fig. S5 and our previous reports [24,31]. 3.5 Catalytic tests of co-feeding water and isopropanol over the commercial MTP catalyst The above experimental results showed that co-feeding ethanol with methanol prolonged the lifetime of the MTP reaction. Here, isopropanol and water were selected as co-feeds to further verify the positive role of a low carbon alcohol. As shown in Fig. 8 , the lifetime of the MTP catalyst improved greatly from 28 h to 55 h when 20 wt.% isopropanol was added; in contrast, the catalyst lifetime decreased to 17 h when 20 wt.% water was added. In addition, C3 = selectivity and C4 = selectivity increased, while C2 = selectivity decreased for the reaction with co-fed isopropanol compared to those using pure methanol and methanol with co-fed water. It should be noted that the CH4 selectivity and C5+ product selectivity of the reaction with co-fed isopropanol were significantly lower than those using pure methanol and methanol with co-fed water. This result indicated that isopropanol closely resembled ethanol in enhancing the lifetime of the MTP catalyst. 3.6 Physiochemical properties of the spent MTP catalysts The acid properties of fresh and spent MTP catalysts were measured by NH3-TPD analysis, and the results are displayed in Fig. 9 a and Table 3 . The total acid amount of the spent MTP catalyst was reduced by 63.0 % compared with that of the fresh catalyst (107.0 μmol/g for the spent catalyst vs. 289.2 μmol/g for the fresh catalyst). More precisely, it was mainly caused by the reduction of moderately strong acid sites and the disappearance of strong acid sites, most likely due to coke deposition on the acid sites. The textural properties of fresh and spent MTP catalysts measured by N2 sorption are shown in Fig. 9b and Fig. S6. Fig. 9b shows that the hysteresis loop of the spent catalyst at P/P0 > 0.45 obviously decreased compared with that of the fresh catalyst, indicating a decrease in mesoporosity (Fig. S6). The comparison of textural properties listed in Table 1 showed that both the surface areas and pore volumes of the micropores and mesopores decreased; however, the surface area of the mesopores increased by 70.1 m2 g−1 after deactivation, which probably originated from the deposited coke after deactivation. Interestingly, another hysteresis loop at a relative pressure of approximately 0.2 was observed, which was ascribed to the variation in state of the adsorbed nitrogen in the micropores of the ZSM-5 zeolite; for instance, from an energetically more favorable position (“liquid phase”) to a more favorable quadrupole–quadrupole interaction (“solid phase”) with increasing relative pressure from 0.1 to 0.2 [32,33]. The framework structures of the MTP catalysts at different times on stream are characterized by FT-IR absorption spectroscopy and displayed in Fig. 10 a. As reported in the literature, the absorbance bands at 449, 550, 800, 1104 and 1230 cm−1 are characteristic of the ZSM-5 framework [34,35]. In particular, the absorbance bands at 449, 800 and 1104 cm−1 are assigned to the internal vibrations of SiO4 or AlO4 tetrahedra [35]. However, the absorbance bands at 550 and 1230 cm−1 are assigned to the double five-ring tetrahedra vibration and the asymmetric stretching of SiO4 and AlO4 tetrahedra in the MFI-type zeolite, respectively [35,36]. The intensities of all bands gradually decreased with time on stream in the MTP reaction, probably due to coke deposition on the Al sites. This could be further verified by the gradual increase of coke content on the MTP catalyst with longer times on stream, as shown in the TG curves in Fig. S7. The 27Al NMR spectra in Fig. S8 shows that the addition of light carbon alcohols did not damage the framework of ZSM-5 zeolite. The negative correlation between the average intensity of those bands and weight loss due to coke removal indicated that coke formation should be responsible for the deactivation of the MTP catalyst. 4 Conclusions The intrinsic effect of co-feeding ethanol on the catalytic performance of an MTP reaction is examined on a commercial MTP catalyst, pure catalysts of ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3, and a ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 mixed catalyst, and shows it is possible to prolong the lifetime of catalysts. The results show that with increasing additions of ethanol, ethylene selectivity and catalyst lifetime gradually increase, while selectivities to CH4 and C5+ products decrease. Ethanol is more reactive than methanol on both the ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 catalysts under the experimental conditions, giving rise to an increased ethylene yield. In addition, ethanol or isopropanol suppresses the conversion of methanol on the γ-Al2O3 matrix, resulting in a lower methane yield. Catalyst deactivation is mainly caused by coke deposition on moderately strong and strong acid sites as well as the blockage of pores by coking. It is hoped that the above discovery will be beneficial for prolonging the lifetime of catalysts in the MTP reaction. Author contributions Rui Feng contributed to the conception of the study. Xinlong Yan and Xiaoyan Hu contributed significantly to analysis and manuscript preparation; Rui Feng and Yixin Zhang performed the data analyses and wrote the manuscript; Jianjun Wu and Zifeng Yan helped perform the analysis with constructive discussions. coredata.dc:description: In this work, co-feeding ethanol with methanol was adopted to prolong the lifetime of a catalyst in a methanol to propylene (MTP) reaction. The effect of an ethanol additive on the MTP reaction was further investigated over an MTP catalyst, pure catalysts of ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3, and a mixed catalyst of ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3, by using methanol and ethanol alone. The catalytic performance showed that with an increasing addition of ethanol, the lifetime of the commercial MTP catalyst was greatly improved, and the selectivity for ethylene correspondingly increased. The catalytic performances of methanol and ethanol on different catalysts showed that the reactivity of methanol and ethanol were in the following order: ethanol on ZSM-5 > ethanol on γ-Al2O3 > methanol on ZSM-5 > methanol on γ-Al2O3. Moreover, coke deposition on moderately strong and strong acid sites and pore blockage were responsible for catalyst deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of co-feeding ethanol on a methanol to propylene (MTP) reaction over a commercial MTP catalyst
